title: Collection Matter: Time Barred Debt: California I was served on 5/17/13 from an in house attorney at a collection agency.
question: I found a collection letter from a different agency dated 3/19/09 trying to collect on the same account. I stopped paying due to severe losses in the economy. I was going to include a copy of this letter to the collection atty & explain that they were suing on a time barred debt & if she would stipulate to a dismissal of the suit & save us both time. Is this worth a try or should I just file my affirmative defense answers. My ex wife has all the files in storage so I cant reference the CC file to see when last payment was made. My ex wife is in Europe for the next 4 weeks & I'm pressed for time. I assumed maybe the atty would figure that an account does not go to collection unless it is past due 60 days or more & realize that the debt is more than likely time barred. Please advise. Thank
answers: The end date on the Statute of Limitations is the date when the lawsuit was filed, not the date when you receive a copy of the lawsuit (Summons and Complaint). I suggest that within 30 days of service, you file an Answer and that you alleged, as one of your defenses, that the SOL has elapsed. After that, you can propound discovery requests asking the plaintiff to produce specified, relevant documents which would show the account history and all assignments of the account. You should sit down with an attorney right away for a consultation. The price for a 1/2 hour or 1 hour consultation will be well worth the cost.

After confirming the debt is indeed time-barred, you should definitely contact the collection attorney. They are in violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act and California Rosenthal Act. Class actions have been brought on identical claims. They'll stipulate to a dismissal.

One is often able to find out the date of last payment by looking at the entry on his/her credit report relating to the account. If it is a debt buyer case, the entry on the credit report may be for the original creditor or the debt buyer, or both. Examine those dates carefully.

Paying on the debt in 2009 may have reset the statute of limitations. Your needs will be best met by consulting with a consumer-rights or bankruptcy (even if bankruptcy is out of the question) attorney to know if you are exposed to judgment.

Best wishes for an outcome you can accept, and please remember to designate a best answer.
